sen.j: 将軍（しょうぐん）は、比較的大きな軍隊の指揮官に与えられる官職および称号の一つ、また軍閥の指導者の地位でもある。
sen.e: Shogun is a job grade and title given to the commander of a relatively large armed force and is also the rank of a military clique leader.
Shogun is a job grade and title given to the commander of a relatively large armed force and is also the rank of a military clique leader.
Shogun is a job grade and title given to the commander of a relatively large armed force and is also the rank of a military clique leader.

sen.j: 称号としての将軍を将軍号ともいう。
sen.e: As title, it is also called Shogun-go (title of General).
As title, it is also called Shogun-go (title of General).
As title, it is also called Shogun-go (title of General).

sen.j: 古来より東洋における軍隊の指揮官の役職名の一つであった。
sen.e: It has been the title of the military commander in the Orient since ancient times.
It has been the title of the military commander in the Orient since ancient times.

sen.j: 外交上または軍隊内の敬称としては閣下が用いられる。
sen.e: In diplomatic situations and inside the armed force, the commanded is addressed as "Kakka" (Your Excellency).

sen.j: 語源
sen.e: Origin of the word
Origin of the word
Origin of the word

sen.j: 将軍は中国において発祥した語であるが、その意味は文字通り、「軍を将いる」ことであり、軍勢を指揮する司令官の官名として使用されたのがはじまりである。
sen.e: The word "shogun" originated in China and meant, as the characters represent, "to lead an army," which was adopted as official position or title of the commander leading the armed forces.
The word "shogun" originated in China and meant, as the characters represent, "to lead an army," which was adopted as official position or title of the commander leading the armed forces.

sen.j: その用例は古くは春秋時代にまで確認することができる。
sen.e: Use of the term dates back as early as the Chunqui period in China.

Use of the term dates back as early as the Chunqui period in China.

sen.j: 後に司馬に代わって軍隊の指揮官の名称として用いられるようになる。
sen.e: Later, it came into use as the rank of an army commander to replace the word Sima (Grand Marshal?).

sen.j: 漢では将軍職は常設ではなく、臨時の官として任ぜられた。
sen.e: In the Han Dynasty, the position of shogun was temporary and given to officials on ad hoc basis.

sen.j: 近代以降の軍隊では、陸軍・空軍・海兵隊の将官以上の階級としては、准将Brigadier General・少将Major General・中将Lieutenant General・大将Generalが存在する（英語表記はアメリカ軍の場合）。
sen.e: In the modern armed forces to date, the titles of high-ranking military officers in the armed, naval and marine forces are Junsho (Brigadier General), Shosho (Major General), Chujo (Lieutenant General) and Taisho (General) (based on ranks in the US armed forces).

sen.j: ただし呼びかけや表記の際の呼称としては、准将から大将、元帥までひっくるめてGeneralが用いられる。
sen.e: However, these top military officers from Brigadier General to General and the General of the Army are addressed and referred to as "Generals."
However, these top military officers from Brigadier General to General and the General of the Army are addressed and referred to as "Generals."

sen.j: 具体的には、XXXX なる氏（名）の将官を、XXXX将軍 等と表記する。

sen.j: 海軍における将官の呼称はAdmiralであり、これの和訳語は「提督」であるが、日本では海軍の場合も准将・少将・中将・大将と陸軍などと同じ階級を用いるため、海軍における将官の呼称としても「将軍」を用いる場合がある。
sen.e: In the naval force, the top officer is called the Admiral, which is translated into Japanese as "Teitoku." Because the same rank titles used in the army, such as Junsho, Shosho, Chujo and Taisho, apply in the navy, there are cases of the title "Shogun" used to address senior naval officers.

In the navy, the top officer is called Admiral, which is translated into Japanese as "Teitoku." Because the same rank titles used in the army, such as Junsho, Shosho, Chujo, and Taisho, apply in the navy, there are cases where the title "Shogun" is used to address senior naval officers.

sen.j: 例えば東郷平八郎は「東郷提督」と呼称すべきであるが、これを「東郷将軍」と記述している例が散見される。
sen.e: An example is Heihachiro TOGO, who should be addressed as "Admiral Togo" but is at times described as "General Togo."

sen.e: In Japan, the title has been in used since the ages described in the Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 崇神天皇に仕えた四道将軍などが初見か。
sen.e: The first mention may be the Shido-Shogun (Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits) who served Emperor Suijin.

sen.j: 東アジア史レベルでの将軍としては倭王武が中国から倭国王安東大将軍に任ぜられたなどの記録がある。
sen.e: In the history of East Asia, there is record of Waobu (the last king of ancient Japan) being appointed King and Grand General of Japan by China.
sen.cmt: 倭国王安東大将軍: King and Grand General of Japan 暫定訳
sen.e: In the history of East Asia, there is record of Waobu (the last king of ancient Japan) being appointed King and Grand General of Japan by China.

sen.j: なお「将軍」の和語での訓は「いくさのかみ」である。
sen.e: It must be noted here that the native Japanese reading for 将軍 is "ikusa-no-kami."
It must be noted here that the native Japanese reading for 将軍 is "ikusa-no-kami."
It must be noted here that the native Japanese reading for 将軍 is "ikusa-no-kami."

sen.j: 日本の律令制では、軍防令24条に将軍の規定がある。
sen.e: In the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), the role of the Shogun is defined in Article 24 of the Gunboryo (the Statute on Military Defense).
In the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), the role of the Shogun is defined in Article 24 of the Gunboryo (the Statute on Military Defense).

sen.j: それによれば、将帥が出征するとき兵一万人以上なら将軍一人、副将軍二人を置く。
sen.e: According to the article, an army of more than 10,000 requires a shogun and two vice-shoguns as commanders.
According to the article, an army of more than 10,000 requires a shogun and two vice-shoguns as commanders.
According to the article, an army of more than 10,000 requires a shogun and two vice-shoguns as commanders.

sen.j: また、三軍ごとに大将軍一人を置く。
sen.e: Also, a Daishogun (commander-in-chief) is to be appointed for every 3 armies.
Also, a Daishogun (commander-in-chief) is to be appointed for every three armies.
Also, a Daishogun (commander-in-chief) is to be appointed for every three armies.

sen.j: しかし実際の任命はこの兵数には基づかず、特に大将軍の下に複数の将軍を置くという形態は一度もとられなかった。
sen.e: However, actual appointments were not based on the size of the army, and the appointment of a number of shoguns under the Daishogun was never practiced.
However, actual appointments were not based on the size of the army, and the appointment of a number of shoguns under the Daishogun was never practiced.
However, actual appointments were not based on the size of the army, and the appointment of a number of shoguns under the Daishogun was never practiced.

sen.j: 将軍は原則として臨時任命であり、任命された事態は、東の蝦夷に対する遠征、南西の隼人に対する遠征、天皇の行幸の護衛、都に来た外国使節や蝦夷・隼人の迎接の四つである。
sen.e: The rank of Shogun was temporary in function as a general rule and was created only in 4 occasions, namely, the campaigns against the Ezo in the east and against the Hayato in southwest Japan, service to protect the Emperor during his travels and for entertainment of foreign guests and representatives of the Ezo and Hayato coming to the capital.

The rank of Shogun was temporary in function as a general rule and was created only on four occasions, namely, in campaigns against the Ezo in the east and against the Hayato in southwest Japan, service to protect the Emperor during his travels and for the entertainment of foreign guests and representatives of the Ezo and Hayato coming to the capital.

The rank of Shogun was temporary in function as a general rule and was created only on four occasions, namely, in campaigns against the Ezo in the east and against the Hayato in southwest Japan, service to protect the Emperor during his travels and for the entertainment of foreign guests and representatives of the Ezo and Hayato coming to the capital.

sen.j: 各将軍はそれぞれ異なる称号を冠し、単なる「将軍」だけの官名はなかった。
sen.e: Each general carried different title descriptions, and none of them were known only as "general."
Each general carried different title descriptions, and none of them were known only as "general."
Each general carried different title descriptions, and none of them were known only as "general."

sen.j: 例示すれば、対蝦夷戦では陸奥鎮東将軍・征越後蝦夷将軍・征狄将軍・征東将軍・征夷将軍など、対隼人戦では討卑賊将軍・征隼人将軍など、行幸と迎接では左将軍・右将軍・御前騎兵将軍・御後騎兵将軍・騎兵大将軍などである。
sen.e: Examples are Mutsu chinto shogun (generalissimo who subdues the barbarians of Mutsu), Seiechigo ezo shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians of Echigo and Ezo), Seiteki shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians of Dewa and Echigo), Seito shogun (Great general who subdues the eastern barbarians) and Seii shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians) in the anti-Ezo war, Tohizoku shogun and Seihayato shogun in the campaigns against Hayato and, in the area of Imperial escorts and diplomatic functions, Sashogun (Commander of the left), Ushogun (Commander of the right), Gozenkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the front cavalry), Gogkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the rear cavalry) and Kihei daishogun (Imperial commander in chief of the cavalry).
sen.cmt: 左将軍・右将軍・御前騎兵将軍・御後騎兵将軍・騎兵大将軍: Sashogun (Commander of the left), Ushogun (Commander of the right), Gozenkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the front cavalry), Gogkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the rear cavalry) and Kihei daishogun (Imperial commander in chief of the cavalry) 暫定訳
sen.e: Examples are Mutsu chinto shogun (generalissimo who subdues the barbarians of Mutsu), Seiechigo ezo shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians of Echigo and Ezo), Seiteki shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians of Dewa and Echigo), Seito shogun (Great general who subdues the eastern barbarians) and Seii shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians) in the anti-Ezo war, Tohizoku shogun and Seihayato shogun in the campaigns against Hayato and, in the area of Imperial escorts and diplomatic functions, Sashogun (Commander of the left), Ushogun (Commander of the right), Gozenkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the front cavalry), Gogkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the rear cavalry) and Kihei daishogun (Imperial commander in chief of the cavalry).

Examples are Mutsu chinto shogun (generalissimo who subdues the barbarians of Mutsu), Seiechigo ezo shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians of Echigo and Ezo), Seiteki shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians of Dewa and Echigo), Seito shogun (Great general who subdues the eastern barbarians) and Seii shogun (Great general who subdues the barbarians) in the anti-Ezo war, Tohizoku shogun and Seihayato shogun in the campaigns against Hayato and, in the area of Imperial escorts and diplomatic functions, Sashogun (Commander of the left), Ushogun (Commander of the right), Gozenkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the front cavalry), Gogkihei shogun (Imperial commander of the rear cavalry) and Kihei daishogun (Imperial commander in chief of the cavalry).

sen.j: 唯一常設されたのが鎮守将軍（後に鎮守府将軍）で、蝦夷に対する防備についた。
sen.e: The only permanent rank was Commander-in-Chief of the Defense (later Chinju-fu shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North)) who was in charge of defense against the Ezo.
The only permanent rank was Commander-in-Chief of Defense (later Chinju-fu shogun or Commander-in-Chief of Defense of the North) in charge of defense against the Ezo.
The only permanent rank was Commander-in-Chief of Defense (later Chinju-fu shogun or Commander-in-Chief of Defense of the North) in charge of defense against the Ezo.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府には、征夷大将軍しか任命されなかったため、征夷大将軍の略称として通用されている。
sen.e: Under the Kamakura shogunate, the only shogun title was Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo), making shogun the abbreviated name for this rank.
Under the Kamakura shogunate, the only shogun title was Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo), making shogun the abbreviated name for this rank.
Under the Kamakura bakufu, the only shogun title was Seii Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo), making shogun the abbreviated name for this rank.

sen.j: これは幕府の支配が固まったことにより事実上、鎮守府将軍の役割が征夷大将軍の職権として吸収されたことによるものとなり、鎌倉幕府の滅亡まで通用される。
sen.e: With shogunate rule gaining stability, the function of the Chinju-fu shogun was in effect absorbed into the authority of the Seii taishogun, which continued to the downfall of the Kamakura shogunate.
With shogunate rule gaining stability, the function of the Chinju-fu shogun was in effect absorbed into the authority of the Seii taishogun, which continued to the downfall of the Kamakura shogunate.
With shogunate rule gaining stability, the function of the Chinju-fu shogun was in effect absorbed into the authority of the Seii taishogun, which continued to the downfall of the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)には鎮守府将軍が復活する。
sen.e: Chinju-fu shogun title was restored in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.
The Chinju-fu shogun title was restored during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.
The Chinju-fu shogun title was restored during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

sen.j: 南朝 (日本)方の北畠親房はわが子 北畠顕家が陸奥守・鎮守府将軍に任ぜられるにあたり、三位以上の将軍は鎮守大将軍とするように奏請。
sen.e: Chikafusa KITABATAKE of the Southern Court requested on the appointment of his son Akiie KITABATAKE as Mutsu no kami and Chinju-fu shogun that shogun ranking higher than Sanmi (Third Rank) be appointed Chinju-fu shogun.

Chikafusa KITABATAKE of the Southern Court requested on the appointment of his son Akiie KITABATAKE as Mutsu no kami and Chinju-fu shogun that a shogun ranking higher than Sanmi (Third Rank) be granted to Chinju-fu shogun.

Chikafusa KITABATAKE of the Southern Court requested on the appointment of his son Akiie KITABATAKE as Mutsu no kami and Chinju-fu shogun that a shogun ranking higher than Sanmi (Third Rank) be granted to Chinju daishogun.

sen.j: これにより顕家は鎮守大将軍として記録されている。
sen.e: It has been recorded that Akiie became Chinju-fu shogun after this.
It has been recorded that Akiie became Chinju-fu shogun after this.
It has been recorded that Akiie became Chinju daishogun after this.

tit.j: 近世の日本史における将軍

sen.j: 室町幕府以降、江戸幕府までは、再び征夷大将軍しか任命されなかったため、征夷大将軍＝将軍という認識が再度生まれる。
sen.e: In the period after Muromachi shogunate to the Edo shogunate, shogun was regarded synonymous to Seii taishogun because the Seii taishogun was the only shogun title.
In the period after the Muromachi shogunate to the Edo shogunate, shogun was regarded synonymous with Seii taishogun because the Seii taishogun was the only shogun title.
In the period after the Muromachi bakufu to the Edo bakufu, shogun was regarded synonymous with Seii taishogun because the Seii taishogun was the only shogun title.

sen.j: しかし、純粋な軍事司令官ではなく現在の総理大臣のように政治のトップ的な存在となっていく。
sen.e: However, it was not strictly a military commander title but because a position of political power similar to the Prime Minister today.
However, it was not strictly a title for a military commander, but reflected a position of political power similar to the Prime Minister of today.
However, it was not strictly a title for a military commander, but reflected a position of political power similar to the Prime Minister of today.

sen.j: そのため、将軍と呼ぶ事に違和感が生じる事となる。
sen.e: For this reason, a sense of discrepancy grew in calling the top leader a shogun.
For this reason, a sense of discrepancy grew from calling the top leader a shogun.
For this reason, a sense of discrepancy grew from calling the top leader a shogun.

sen.j: こうした事から、一般的には公方様、御所様、上様などという呼び方（時代によって異なる）がなされるようになっていった。
sen.e: This led to the use of titles such as Kubo-sama, Gosho-sama and Uesama (used variably depending on the period of history) when referring to the ruler.
This led to the use of titles such as Kubo-sama, Gosho-sama and Uesama (used variably depending on the period of history) when referring to the ruler.
This led to the use of titles such as Kubo-sama, Gosho-sama and Uesama (used variably depending on the period of history) when referring to the ruler.

sen.j: 外交呼称として対外的に「日本国王」「日本国大君」を称した場合もある。
sen.e: In diplomatic title, there are cases of the ruler being called King of Japan or Tycoon of Japan.
As a diplomatic title, there are cases of the ruler being called the King of Japan or Tycoon of Japan.
As a diplomatic title, there are cases of the ruler being called the King of Japan or Tycoon of Japan.

sen.j: 隠居した前将軍を大御所という。
sen.e: A retired ruler is called Ogosho.
A retired ruler is called Ogosho.
A retired ruler is called Ogosho.

sen.j: しかし、1867年（慶応 (元号)3年）に江戸幕府の15代将軍徳川慶喜が大政奉還を行なった。
sen.e: However, the 15th shogun Keiki TOKUGAWA of the Edo shogunate implemented Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) in 1867.
However, the fifteenth shogun Keiki TOKUGAWA of the Edo shogunate implemented Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) in 1867.
However, the fifteenth shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA of the Edo bakufu implemented Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor) in 1867.

sen.j: この後、明治政府が征夷大将軍の地位と幕府制度を廃止した。
sen.e: Later, the Meiji government abolished the title of Seii taishogun and the shogunate system.
Later, the Meiji government abolished the title of Seii taishogun and the shogunate system.
Later, the Meiji government abolished the title of Seii taishogun and the shogunate system.

sen.j: このため、将軍の地位を得たのは徳川将軍家が事実上最後となっている。
sen.e: For this reason, the Tokugawa family was the last to hold the title of shogun.
For this reason, the Tokugawa family was the last to hold the title of shogun.
For this reason, the Tokugawa family was the last to hold the title of shogun.

sen.j: 西欧語に借用された shogun は、特に日本の征夷大将軍を指す。
sen.e: Shogun loaned into Western languages point exclusively to Seii taishogun of Japan.
Shogun borrowed by Western languages point exclusively to Seii taishogun of Japan.
Shogun borrowed by Western languages point exclusively to Seii taishogun of Japan.

sen.j: また、『将軍 SHOGUN』は、ジェームズ・クラヴェルの小説、小説を原作とした映画・テレビドラマである。
sen.e: Also, "Shogun" is a novel by James Clavell, on which a film and a TV drama series have been produced.
Also, "Shogun" is a novel by James Clavell, on which a film and a TV drama series have been produced.
Also, "Shogun" is a novel by James Clavell, on which a film and a TV drama series have been produced.

tit.j: 前近代中国における将軍

sen.j: 漢代に於ける将軍は軍の指揮官として必要な時に皇帝により置かれたもので、最上級の大将軍は三公にも匹敵する重職であった。
sen.e: In the age of the Han Dynasty, the shogun was a rank granted to the military commander by the Emperor when such a leader was necessary, and the topmost commander-in-chief was regarded equivalent to the San Gong (Three Dukes).

In the age of the Han Dynasty, the shogun was a rank granted to the military commander by the Emperor when such a leader was necessary, and the topmost commander-in-chief was regarded equivalent to the San Gong (Three Dukes).

In the age of the Han Dynasty, the shogun was a rank granted to the military commander by the Emperor when such a leader was necessary, and the topmost commander-in-chief was regarded equivalent to the San Gong (Three Dukes).

sen.j: その下に驃騎将軍・衛将軍・車騎将軍があり、その下に上将軍・伏波将軍など臨時に任命される雑号将軍がある。
sen.e: Under the commander-in chief are the general of the cavalry, general of the guards and general of the cavalry and chariots, who were in turn served by Jo-shogun (grand general), general of the hidden waves and others who served on temporary basis.
sen.cmt: 驃騎将軍・衛将軍・車騎将軍: general of the cavalry, general of the guards and general of the cavalry and chariots伏波将軍: General of the hidden waves 暫定訳
sen.e: Under the commander-in chief are the general of the cavalry, general of the guards, and general of the cavalry and chariots, who were in turn served by Jo-shogun (grand general), general of the hidden waves and others who served on temporary basis.

Under the commander-in chief are the general of the cavalry, general of the guards, and general of the cavalry and chariots, who were in turn served by Jo-shogun (grand general), general of the hidden waves and others who served on temporary basis.

sen.j: 後に戦乱などによって将軍号が増加し、南朝 (中国)梁 (南朝)の蕭衍が将軍号を整理した際には12班で合わせて125号に分類整理されたという。
sen.e: Subsequent wars led to increase in the number of shogun titles, that there were 125 titles for 12 organizations when Sho En (Xiao Yan) of Liang (Southern Court) of the Southern Dynasty systematized the titles.

Subsequent wars led to increase in the number of shogun titles, and there were 125 titles for twelve organizations when Sho En (Xiao Yan) of Liang (Southern Court) of the Southern Dynasty systematized the titles.

Subsequent wars led to increase in the number of shogun titles, and there were 125 titles for twelve organizations when Sho En (Xiao Yan) of Liang (Southern Court) of the Southern Dynasty systematized the titles.

sen.j: 唐の時代には、官職としての将軍の他に武散官の称号としての将軍も並存した。
sen.e: In the Tang Dynasty, there were shogun titles for bureacratic rank and also for Imperial busankan rank.
In the Tang Dynasty, there were shogun titles for bureacratic rank and also for Imperial busankan rank.
In the Tang Dynasty, there were shogun titles for bureacratic rank and also for Imperial busankan rank.

sen.j: 北宋では、武散官の称号としてのみ残され、それも神宗 (宋)の時代に廃されて「大夫」「郎」と改称された。
sen.e: In the Northern Sung Dynasty, only the title of busankan remained but later disappeared in the Shenzong Dynasty, when it was renamed taifu and ro.
In the Northern Sung Dynasty, only the title of busankan remained, but later disappeared in the Shenzong Dynasty, when it was renamed taifu and ro.
In the Northern Sung Dynasty, only the title of busankan remained, but later disappeared in the Shenzong Dynasty, when it was renamed taifu and ro.

sen.j: 元 (王朝)の時代に武散官の称号として復活し、続く明の時代には総兵官及びその麾下である軍指揮官の官職名としても復活した。
sen.e: The title was revived and conferred to bunsankan rank during the Yuan Dynasty and also as title for the military commander in chief and the subordinate commanders in the Ming Dynasty that followed.

The title was revived and conferred to the bunsankan rank during the Yuan Dynasty and also as title for the military commander in chief and the subordinate commanders in the Ming Dynasty that followed.

The title was revived and conferred to the busankan rank during the Yuan Dynasty and also as title for the military commander in chief and the subordinate commanders in the Ming Dynasty that followed.

sen.j: 清の時代には臨時の官職として大将軍が設置されたことがあるものの、常設官においては総兵官としての将軍の称号は再び廃されて、副将以下の軍指揮官及び駐防八旗兵の司令官の称号として残り近代に至る。
sen.e: In Qing Dynasty, the title of Daishogun was used as temporary rank but was scrapped once again for use a permanent title referring to the top military commander, remaining as title used for military officers of vice shogun or lower or commander of the eight armies serving in defense against external attacks.
sen.cmt: 駐防八旗兵：Eight armies serving in defense against external attacks 暫定訳
sen.e: In the Qing Dynasty, the title of Daishogun was used as a temporary rank, but was scrapped once again for use as a permanent title referring to the top military commander, remaining as title used for military officers of vice shogun or lower or commander of the eight armies serving in defense against external attacks.

In the Qing Dynasty, the title of Daishogun was used as a temporary rank, but was scrapped once again for use as a permanent title referring to the top military commander, remaining as title used for military officers of vice shogun or lower or commander of the eight armies serving in defense against external attacks.

tit.j: 国家指導者の敬称としての将軍
tit.e: Shogun as title of respect for sovereigns
Shogun as title of respect for sovereigns
Shogun as title of respect for sovereigns

sen.j: 国際的には、軍事政権や革命政権に由来する政権において最高指導者または最高権力者が、政権掌握当時の将軍位を意図的に職位として名乗ったり国民の間に流布したりしている例がある。
sen.e: On the international level, there are instances of the title of shogun being adopted deliberately as rank by the top commander or the top political leader in a regime that emerged from military rule or following a revolution and circulated among the people to gain recognition.

On the international level, there are instances of the title of shogun being adopted deliberately as a rank by the top commander or the top political leader in a regime that emerged from military rule or when following a revolution and circulated among the people to gain recognition.

On the international level, there are instances of the title of shogun being adopted deliberately as a rank by the top commander or the top political leader in a regime that emerged from military rule or when following a revolution and circulated among the people to gain recognition.

sen.j: ただしこれらの中には、最高権力者の独裁状態であると一般的に見なされる国家における統治者側のイメージ戦略に過ぎないケースもある。
sen.e: However, the title in some cases had been used as part of a strategy to enhance the image of the person in power in a nation that is generally perceived to be a dictatorship.
However, the title in some cases had been used as part of a strategy to enhance the image of the person in power in a nation that is generally perceived to be a dictatorship.
However, the title in some cases had been used as part of a strategy to enhance the image of the person in power in a nation that is generally perceived to be a dictatorship.

sen.j: また終戦直後の日本における連合国軍最高司令官総司令部のダグラス・マッカーサー将軍のように、敗戦国に対する占領統治において、軍の将軍位にある者が現地の最高責任者に就くケースもしばしば見られる。
sen.e: There are also a number of cases in which a top military officer representing the forces occupying a defeated nation assumes the office of its top political leader, such as General Douglas MacArthur of the General Headquarters, Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Japan after the end of World War II.

There are also a number of cases in which a top military officer representing the forces occupying a defeated nation assumes the office of its top political leader, such as General Douglas MacArthur of the General Headquarters, Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Japan after the end of World War II.

There are also a number of cases in which a top military officer representing the forces occupying a defeated nation assumes the office of its top political leader, such as General Douglas MacArthur of the General Headquarters, Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers in Japan after the end of World War II.

sen.j: また、パナマのマヌエル・ノリエガ、イラクのサッダーム・フセイン、朝鮮民主主義人民共和国の金日成・金正日父子なども「将軍」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Also, Manuel Noriega of Panama, Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Kim Il Song and son Kim Jong Il of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea were called "shoguns."
Also, Manuel Noriega of Panama, Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Kim Il Song and son Kim Jong Il of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea were called "shogun."
Also, Manuel Noriega of Panama, Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Kim Il Song and son Kim Jong Il of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea were called "shogun."

sen.j: 金正日については「将軍様(将軍ニム)」とも呼ばれるが、北朝鮮や大韓民国では上司や上位者に対しては肩書きの下に「ニム()」つまり日本でいう「様」をつける習慣がある。
sen.e: In the case of Kim Jong Il, his title of shogun is accompanied by "nim," which is used in DPRK and the Republic of Korea as address to show deference to a higher-ranking person, much in the same way "sama" is used in Japanese.

In the case of Kim Jong Il, his title of shogun is accompanied by "nim," which is used in DPRK and the Republic of Korea as address to show deference to a higher-ranking person, much in the same way "sama" is used in Japanese.

In the case of Kim Jong Il, his title of shogun is accompanied by "nim," which is used in DPRK and the Republic of Korea as address to show deference to a higher-ranking person, much in the same way "sama" is used in Japanese.

sen.j: そのため、韓国・朝鮮では社長様、部長様、先生様などの言葉は一般的に使用されている。
sen.e: For this reason, the term is commonly used in the two countries after titles such as company president, departmen chief, teacher, etc.
For this reason, the term is commonly used in the two countries after titles such as company president, departmen chief, teacher, etc.
For this reason, the term is commonly used in the two countries after titles such as company president, department chief, teacher, etc.

sen.j: 金正日もまた、その延長線上で「ニム()」をつけて呼ばれているだけであり、意識的に彼だけを「様」づけしているわけではない。
sen.e: The "nim" after the shogun title for Kim Jong Il therefore is used as application of this custom and is not used exclusively for the leader.
The "nim" after the shogun title for Kim Jong Il therefore is used as an application of this custom and is not used exclusively for the leader.
The "nim" after the shogun title for Kim Jong Il therefore is used as an application of this custom and is not used exclusively for the leader.

sen.j: 三菱自動車工業のオフロード車「三菱・パジェロ」のイギリスにおける名称(SHOGUN)。
